(五重塔, "Five Story Pagoda").  The Laurel to Kindo's Hardy, this graceful five-story pagoda is the oldest in Japan and a much-copied archetype.  Located in the Kairo.
(大講堂, "Great Teaching Hall").  On the north side of the Kairo, this hall dating from the Heian era (990) is one of the largest buildings in Horyuji.

(大宝蔵殿 "Great Treasure Store Hall").  A modern building housing a permanent exhibition of some of the temple's wealth, accumulated over a millennium. Contains many objects which were originally part of Horyuji, including the nationally famous Kudara Kannon.
(東大門, "East Great Gate"). This stately gate was once another entrance into the temple, but now marks the division between the west and the east halves of the complex.

(夢殿, "Dream Pavilion"). Constructed in 739 on the site of the building where Prince Shotoku once lived. The Kuze Kannon statue within is only shown to visitors between April 11-May 18 and October 22-November 23.

(中宮寺).  A separate temple just outside the northeastern tip of the complex, originally the residence of Shotoku's mother and famed for its statue of the boddhisattva Miroku (the Future Buddha). The building where the statue is housed is an ugly modern construction. This temple is owned by a competing Buddhist sect and a separate admission of ¥500 is charged.

From here you can walk 5 minutes south to the main road and catch a bus back to the station.
